member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Command.TrySignalAsync(Medallion.Shell.CommandSignal)
member.summary:
Attempts to send the specified to each underlying the current . Returns true if at least one received the signal and false otherwise.
There are several reasons that signaling could fail, for example: * The provided signal number is not valid for the OS * The has already exited * On Windows, signals can only be sent to console processes

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Command.GetOutputAndErrorLines
member.summary:
Returns a single streaming which merges the outputs of on and . This is similar to doing 2>&1 on the command line.
Merging at the line level means that interleaving of the outputs cannot break up any single lines

member.name: P:Medallion.Shell.CommandSignal.ControlC
member.summary:
The input interupt signal (CTRL_C_EVENT on Windows, SIGINT on Unix).
By default, this will terminate the process, but processes may register a handle for the signal in order to do something else instead (e. g. graceful shutdown)

member.name: T:Medallion.Shell.MonoUnixCommandLineSyntax
member.summary: Mono on unix uses a different, incompatible method of splitting the command line into arguments than is the default on Windows. This is referenced here: https://bugzilla.xamarin.com/show_bug.cgi?id=19296, although the "quick fix" it mentions does not fully account for the differences.

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.PlatformCompatibilityHelper.SafeStart(System.Diagnostics.Process,System.IO.StreamWriter@,System.IO.StreamReader@,System.IO.StreamReader@)
member.summary:
Starts the given and captures the standard IO streams. This method works around Mono.Android-specific issue https://github.com/madelson/MedallionShell/issues/22, where a process that exits quickly causes the initialization of the standard input writer to fail (since setting AutoFlush = true triggers a write which on Mono crashes for a closed process).
If https://github.com/mono/mono/issues/8478 is ever addressed, we wouldn't need this any more.

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Shell.Options.DisposeOnExit(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
If specified, the underlying object for the command will be disposed when the process exits. This means that there is no need to dispose of a .
This also means that cannot be reliably accessed, since it may exit at any time.
Defaults to true

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Shell.Options.Syntax(Medallion.Shell.CommandLineSyntax)
member.summary: Specifies the to use for escaping arguments. Defaults to an appropriate value for the current platform

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Shell.Options.Timeout(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Specifies a timeout after which the process should be killed. Defaults to

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Shell.Options.Encoding(System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary:
Specifies an to be used for StandardOutput, StandardError, and StandardInput.
By default, will use for output streams and for input streams.
Note that the output encodings can be set individually via . If you need to specify different encodings for different streams, use this method to set the StandardInput encoding and then use to further override the two output encodings

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Shell.Options.CancellationToken(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Specifies a which will abort the command when canceled. When a command is aborted, the underlying process will be killed as if using

member.name: F:Medallion.Shell.Signals.WindowsProcessSignaler.SignalFromCurrentProcessLock
member.summary: Since signaling from the current process requires mucking with global state (CTRL handlers), we limit to one concurrent access.

member.name: T:Medallion.Shell.Streams.CompatibilityStandardInputWrapperStream
member.summary:
On .NET Core and .NET Framework on Windows, writing to the standard input after the process exits is a noop.
However, on Mono this will throw a "Write Fault" exception (https://github.com/madelson/MedallionShell/issues/6) while .NET Core on Linux throws a "Broken Pipe" exception (https://github.com/madelson/MedallionShell/issues/46).
This class wraps the underlying to provide consistent behavior across platforms.

member.name: F:Medallion.Shell.Streams.InternalProcessStreamReader.processStream
member.summary: The underlying from the

member.name: F:Medallion.Shell.Streams.Pipe.MaxStableSize
member.summary: The maximum size at which the pipe will be left empty. Using 2 * helps prevent thrashing if data is being pushed through the pipe at that rate

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Streams.Pipe.UpdateSignalsNoLock
member.summary:
MA: I used to have the signals updated in various ways and in various places throughout the code. Now I have just one function that sets both signals to the correct values. This is called from , , , and .
While it may seem like this does extra work, nearly all cases are necessary. For example, we used to say "signal bytes available if count > 0" at the end of . The problem is that we could have the following sequence of operations: 1. blocks on 2. writes and signals 3. wakes up 4. Another call writes and re-signals 5. reads ALL content and returns, leaving signaled (invalid)
This new implementation avoids this because the call inside will properly unsignal after it consumes ALL the contents

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Streams.PipeHelpers.CopyToAsyncWithAutoFlush(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Similar to , but performs a following each . The benefit of this is that data moves through the pipe instead of becoming caught in the write buffer of

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Streams.ProcessStreamReader.Discard
member.summary: Discards all output from the underlying stream. This prevents the process from blocking because the output pipe's buffer is full without wasting any memory on buffering the output

member.name: M:Medallion.Shell.Streams.ProcessStreamReader.StopBuffering
member.summary: By default, the underlying stream output is buffered to prevent the process from blocking because the output pipe's buffer is full. Calling this method disables this behavior. This is useful when it is desirable to have the process block while waiting for output to be read

member.name: T:Medallion.Shell.WindowsCommandLineSyntax
member.summary:
Provides functionality for windows.
Note that while this class uses windows parsing rules, .NET Core actually follows the same rules when parsing into argv for unix-like systems. Therefore, this class is actually cross-platform compatible. The one exception is Mono running on Unix, which uses a different escaping scheme.

member.summary: Provides functionality for windows
